keyTakeAways: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old from Ichikawa, Japan, became a global figure after scoring a game-winning 38-yard field goal against Stanford during the NCAA college football season.
He taught himself to kick football by watching YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle Seahawks kicker Jason Myers, who responded to him on Instagram.

Matsuzawa's journey includes overcoming personal setbacks, such as failing an exam in Japan and losing motivation, and financial hardship, including working as a waiter and cutting his own hair to save money.
His parents supported him by making a significant sacrifice, relocating to the U.S. to help him pursue his dream, and he was awarded a scholarship to the University of Hawaii.
Matsuzawa is majoring in sports management and is inspired by Japanese baseball star Shohei Ohtani, whose mindset and work ethic he emulates.
He aims to one day play in the NFL, becoming the first Japanese national to do so, and dreams of winning a Super Bowl and signing a big contract.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Kansei Matsuzawa, a 26-year-old placekicker from Ichikawa, Japan, made global headlines by scoring a game-winning 38-yard field goal against Stanford during the NCAA college football season. Despite having no coaches or English skills in Japan, he taught himself to kick and speak English by studying YouTube videos of NFL players, including Seattle kicker Jason Myers, who personally responded to him. After failing an exam and losing motivation, Matsuzawa found renewed purpose after attending an NFL game. He moved to the U.S., studied at Hocking College in Ohio to improve his English, and was awarded a scholarship to the University of Hawaii. His journey, marked by financial hardship, personal sacrifice, and unwavering determination, exemplifies the power of self-driven ambition. Inspired by Japanese baseball star Shohei Ohtani, Matsuzawa dreams of playing in the NFL, becoming the first Japanese national to do so, and eventually winning a Super Bowl. His story is a testament to resilience, global connectivity through digital media, and the transformative role of mentorship in sports.
title: The NFL hopeful from Japan who learned to kick on YouTube
